title: Cucumber & BDD Quiz
description: Test your knowledge of Cucumber and Behavior-Driven Development

questions.question: What is Cucumber primarily used for?
questions.explanation: Cucumber is a BDD tool that allows you to write executable specifications in plain language (Gherkin) that anyone can understand.

questions.question: What is the file extension for Gherkin feature files?
questions.explanation: Gherkin feature files use the .feature extension. They contain the scenarios written in Gherkin syntax (Given-When-Then).

questions.question: Gherkin is a business-readable domain-specific language.
questions.explanation: Gherkin is designed to be readable by non-programmers. It uses plain English syntax with keywords like Given, When, Then to describe behavior.

questions.d: Which keywords are the main building blocks of Gherkin scenarios?
questions.explanation: The main Gherkin keywords are Given (precondition), When (action), Then (assertion), and And/But for adding more steps.

questions.question: What does the 'Feature' keyword represent in a Gherkin file?

options.text: A high-level description of a software feature

questions.explanation: The Feature keyword provides a high-level description of a software feature. It groups related scenarios together and includes a narrative description.

questions.question: What is a Step Definition in Cucumber?

options.text: Code that maps a Gherkin step to actual automation

questions.explanation: Step Definitions are code blocks (in Java, JavaScript, Ruby, etc.) that implement the automation for each Gherkin step. They connect plain text steps to executable code.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'Background' section in a Gherkin feature file?

options.text: To run tests in the background
To define steps that run before each scenario

questions.explanation: Background allows you to define steps that run before every scenario in the feature file. It's useful for setting up common preconditions.

questions.question: Scenario Outline in Cucumber allows data-driven testing.
questions.explanation: Scenario Outline uses Examples tables to run the same scenario with different sets of data, enabling data-driven testing in BDD.

questions.question: What is the purpose of tags in Cucumber?

options.text: To organize and filter scenarios for execution

questions.explanation: Tags (@tag) are labels used to organize scenarios. You can run specific tags using command line options, useful for filtering tests by type (e.g., @smoke, @regression).

questions.question: Which Gherkin step is appropriate for asserting a result?
questions.explanation: The 'Then' step is used for assertions - it describes the expected outcome or result. For example: 'Then I should see the success message'.

questions.question: What is the purpose of Hooks in Cucumber?

options.text: To run code before/after scenarios or steps

questions.explanation: Hooks are blocks of code that run before or after scenarios or individual steps. Common hooks include @Before and @After for setup and teardown.

questions.question: Cucumber supports multiple programming languages.
questions.explanation: Cucumber has implementations (called 'cukes') for many languages including Java (Cucumber-JVM), JavaScript (Cucumber.js), Ruby, Python, and .NET (SpecFlow).

questions.question: What is the purpose of 'Scenario Context' or 'World' in Cucumber?

options.text: To share state between step definitions within a scenario

questions.explanation: Scenario Context (or World in older Cucumber) allows step definitions to share state and data within a scenario. It's used for passing data between steps.

questions.question: What does the 'Examples' keyword define in a Scenario Outline?

options.text: A table of test data values to substitute in the scenario

questions.explanation: Examples provides a table where each row represents a test case. The placeholder variables (<variable>) in the scenario are replaced with values from each row.

questions.question:
What will this Gherkin code test?

Feature: Login
  Scenario: Successful login
    Given I am on the login page
    When I enter valid credentials
    Then I should be logged in

options.text: The entire login flow from page load to successful authentication
This will error due to missing steps

questions.explanation: This scenario tests the complete login flow: 1) Navigate to login page (Given), 2) Enter credentials (When), 3) Verify successful login (Then).

questions.question: What is the purpose of 'Data Tables' in Gherkin?

options.text: To pass structured data to step definitions

questions.explanation: Data Tables allow you to pass structured data directly in the feature file. They're useful for testing scenarios with multiple sets of input data in a single step.

questions.question: The 'And' keyword can be used after Given, When, or Then steps.
questions.explanation: 'And' (and 'But') can be used after any step to add additional steps of the same type, making scenarios more readable.

questions.question: What is the main benefit of BDD with Cucumber?

options.text: Collaboration - non-technical stakeholders can understand and contribute to test specifications

questions.explanation: The main benefit of BDD/Cucumber is improved collaboration. Tests written in Gherkin (plain English) allow developers, QA, and business stakeholders to communicate effectively.

questions.question: You want to test login with invalid credentials 3 times. What Cucumber feature would you use?

options.text: Scenario Outline with Examples table containing 3 test cases

questions.explanation: Scenario Outline with an Examples table allows you to test the same scenario with different data. Create a table with 3 rows of invalid credentials to test each case.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the Cucumber Reports plugin?

options.text: To generate HTML reports showing test results and coverage

questions.explanation: Cucumber Reports (and similar plugins likeExtent Reports) generate visual HTML reports showing test results, execution time, and which scenarios passed or failed.
